ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
SBS DOUBLE-DECKER BUSES
(Particulars)


    1. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for National Development and Communications (a) how many Singapore Bus Service Limited double-decker buses there are on the road today; (b) whether any study has been carried out to establish the reasons for the unpopularity of those buses, and, if so, what are the results of the study and what remedial measures have been taken; (c) whether more double-decker buses will be introduced in the future; (d) is it more

Column: 1236

economical to operate those buses; and (e) how many accidents involving such buses have occurred to date.

     The Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the answers are as follows:

    (a) There are 20 double-deckers in operation today.

    (b) No systematic study has been conducted yet. However, from observations and conductors' opinions, it can be said that the double-deckers are not unpopular. They are well received by commuters generally. In fact, their bigger capacity, that is 85 seats

Column: 1237

and 12 standee space compared with 41 and 32 respectively for long wheel-base single deck buses, makes them very popular.

    We are trying them out under two operational modes: one-man-operation and two-man operation. In both cases, we find them well utilised by commuters.

    (c) SBS is very encouraged by the initial success of the double-decker buses and is actively considering the acquisition of more units.

    (d) SBS' calculations show that the operating cost is less for a double-decker bus than a long wheel-base single deck bus. In terms of capacity, two of them are equivalent to three long wheel-base single deck buses.

    (e) During the nine months of operation, the 20 double-decker buses have encountered 28 minor traffic accidents,

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Chai Chong Yii): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I continue with my reply by first giving a summary of what we have done or what is being planned, to enlighten Members.

(1) Review of Primary and Secondary Education

    In the last two years, the following adjustments to our education system have

Column: 1238

been made: abolition of automatic promotion in primary and secondary schools, introduction of the Basic Course at the primary level, establishment of the Junior Trainee Scheme to place Basic Course leavers in jobs in industries, and expansion of vocationally-biased courses at the Adult Education Board and the Industrial Training Board for less academically-inclined pupils at secondary levels. The aim of all these adjustments is to minimise wastage of our human resources through better co-ordination of our education programmes with our manpower needs.

(2) Pre-U Education for Chinese Stream Students

    The recent adjustment to Pre-University education for Chinese stream students was necessitated by the changeover to English medium of instruction for new intakes at Nanyang University. The options offered are to help Chinese stream Pre-University students upgrade their proficiency in English language, thereby enhancing their prospects of University education or employment.

(3) Bilingualism

    The adjustments are in line with our policy of bilingualism. At present a pupil has to pass the Primary School Leaving Examination (PSLE) before he is allowed to proceed to Secondary 1. In order to pass PSLE a pupil must be quite good in the first and second languages because of the following weightage given to the four required subjects: 
   First language               ...  200
   Second language              ...  200
   Mathematics                  ...  100
   Science                      ...  100
Although under the above system a pupil very good in one language and very poor in the other can still pass his PSLE if his Mathematics and Science are both far above average, it is unlikely for many pupils to get through it this way. Besides, my Ministry is now placing greater emphasis on the study of the first and second languages in primary schools as younger pupils can learn them

Column: 1239

easier. This is being implemented stage by stage even at the expense of learning less of other subjects which they can catch up when they are in the secondary schools. Minimum language qualifications for admission to Pre-U courses have also been raised such that by 1980, P6 for First Language and P7 for Second Language will be required. For Members' information, this year, only a P8 is required. This, together with the special concessions given to pupils who score Distinctions in first and second languages, will actively promote effective bilingualism amongst our more able pupils who will be our future leaders. Where feedback has shown that children are unable to cope successfully with the learning of two languages, the approach has been modified as in the Basic Course which stressed the learning of one language and the acquisition of only basic oral skills in the Second Language. Our policy of bilingualism will eventually lead to the ultimate emergence of a national type Singaporean school which uses two languages, English and Mandarin, Malay or Tamil as media of instruction.

(4) Implementation of Adjustments

    These adjustments were implemented after planning by the Ministry of Education. In the preparations prior to implementation, all available resources were marshalled to ensure that the needs of pupils were not overlooked and that teachers implementing the adjustments are given the necessary support in terms of orientation and retraining. Guidelines to implement the policy of promotion and retention at the primary level were issued and discussed with principals, followed by syllabuses and specifications on assessment of attainment at each level. Basic Course syllabuses were issued together with teaching materials and textbooks. For the secondary level, guidelines on implementation of promotion and retention have been issued and discussed with principals, and detailed recommendations on formulation of schemes of work and assessment are being completed for issue to schools soon.

(5) Monitoring for Improvements

    Implementation of all adjustments are monitored. The content of the first orientation course for teachers assigned to the Basic Course had been revised. Feedback on Basic Course syllabuses and materials have been obtained and will be taken into account in revisions of syllabuses. A total of 2,342 or 91% of Basic Course pupils available for placement have been emplaced in jobs. A survey of pupils who did not enrol in the Basic Course in 1978 has shown that about half of those who did not enrol have found their own employment while a quarter, mainly girls, preferred to stay at home.

(6) Implementation of Options for Chinese Pre-U Students

    The Scheme of Options for Pre-U students in the Chinese stream is being implemented in the Junior Colleges where facilities and the environment for English language learning are better than at Pre-U centres. Students are also given options to select the one most appropriate to their needs. Special tutorials will be conducted for students and every effort will be made to help them adjust. There is also the choice of reverting to the Chinese medium after six months for those really unable to cope. To implement the Scheme,

30    Arts and Science English medium graduate teachers have been selected.

(7) Foreign Language Teaching

    Attention has also been given to other areas of the education system. The teaching of Japanese, French and later German is being promoted in secondary schools. This will develop a core of persons with the requisite foreign language skills to meet the nation's needs in future.

(8) Moral-Social Education

    The need for more systematic moral-social education in schools is being emphasised. A project has been initiated to obtain feedback on such activities currently conducted in schools and to encourage schools to share their experience and pool resources. Work ethics is also emphasised in the Basic Course curriculum and the AEB Extension Education

Column: 1241

Programme for junior trainees, while correct attitudes towards manual work are inculcated through more "Use Your Hands" programmes in schools.

(9) Education for the Handicapped

    Assistance is being given by the Ministry of Education to voluntary associations catering to the educational needs of handicapped children in addition to financial grants from the Ministry of Social Affairs and the Ministry of Health. Assistance from the Ministry of Education by way of secondment of teaching personnel and provision of suitable physical facilities will be increased. The resources that can be channelled to the education of the handicapped is limited at present as educational provision for normal children must be accorded priority.

(10) Teacher Recruitment

    Steps are being taken to attract more high-calibre graduates into the Education Service. There are generous awards of scholarships and bursaries for teaching by the Public Service Commission. To make it more attractive to prospective teachers, the Ministry is revising the scheme of service for Education Officers. We expect to finalise the scheme within a few months.

(11) In-Service Education

    Many of our serving teachers were recruited in the crash training programmes of the 1950s and 1960s. Present in-service courses as well as those to be mounted under the 1978-81 5-year Rolling Plan of In-Service Education will upgrade their professional competence and extend their expertise. In-service courses at the Language Project Centre at Portsdown Road as well as workshops on political, economic and social awareness conducted at the National Youth Leadership Training Institute will give new insights and strengthen the general capability of teachers and enhance their job performance.
2.45 p.m.

(12) Promotion Exercise

    Any promotion exercise because it is competitive leaves those who are

Column: 1242

unsuccessful disappointed. The system in the last promotion exercise was adopted after thorough examination of all other possible alternatives and, as far as is possible within a sector of 18,000 employees, assessed by over 500 supervisors, has been a fair system. More teachers were promoted in this exercise than at previous exercises.

    The general complaint of Members is that criteria for promotion are not made known. It is not possible for the Ministry to set out in detail all the requirements officers should meet to merit promotion. The broad outlines were published in the Teachers' Rostrum, a Ministry publication given free to all staff in the Education Service. Briefly, the entire record of an officer, his ECA duties, community service, his self-development and national awards are all taken into consideration. An officer has to be assessed against the role he functions in and in relation to others functioning in the same role. The Ministry is attempting to improve the evaluative criteria so that the reporting can be more objective. A revised staff confidential report form has been drafted and has been commented on by a number of principals at the principals' residential seminar held in February. Their reaction has been quite favourable so far.

(13) Morale of Teachers

    The view that morale in the teaching profession is low is not substantiated. The findings of a recent Survey on Teachers showed that 75% of teachers found satisfaction in teaching and were satisfied with their current postings. The survey also established that the majority of teachers had no complaints about their ECA load which is an integral part of the educative process.

(14) Consultation with School Principals

    Closer rapport between Headquarters and schools has been established through the regular visits of senior HQ officers to schools. A continuous dialogue has been established through residential seminars for principals. Principals have been delegated with greater authority. Financial procedures have also

Column: 1243

been simplified. Consequential desirable effects are the solutions found to the more pressing problems such as in the maintenance of school plants and the improvement of the physical facilities of schools. Such improvements are in addition to the current School Building Programme under which it is planned that by 1980/81, a total of 66 schools will be built.

(15) School Administration

    To strengthen administration in schools, courses in educational administration are being conducted for newly appointed principals and senior assistants to equip them with the necessary management skills.

(16) Systematic Feedback and Monitoring

    To obtain regular feedback on all activities and aspects of the school programme and monitor all measures introduced in the education system, a Planning and Review Branch was set up in October 1976. The monitoring mechanism set up by the Branch has to date obtained feedback on the teaching of Science and Mathematics in English in non-English medium schools and on nine areas of the school programme including school administration, staff, curriculum, ECA and examinations. Feedback obtained on the school programme will be discussed at a series of Principals' Conference scheduled over the next four months. The Branch also co-ordinated the monitoring of the implementation of the Basic Course, the Junior Trainee Scheme and the planning for the implementation of the revisions to secondary education. New measures to be monitored include the teaching of foreign languages, the Assistance Plan for Chinese Schools and the optional third year Pre-U Course for Chinese stream students.

(17) Conclusion

    The developments in education over the last two years have firstly, made adjustments to the structure of our education system for better co-ordination with national manpower

Column: 1244

needs and individual educational needs and capacities; secondly, directed all efforts at improving the quality of teachers and meeting teacher shortages; and finally, strengthened organisation and administration of the whole system by careful planning.

    Sir, having replied generally on what we have done in the Education Ministry, I would like to go back to a few points raised by hon. Members yesterday.

    The Member for Anson asked how successful was the recruitment exercise, and he would also like to know how many resigned from the Education Service. I have only figures for last year. Our recruitment for the Institute of Education in July 1977 was 150 graduates and 95 non-graduates. In the 1978 recruitment, there were 86 graduates and 114 non-graduates. Besides the Institute of Education recruitment, there were direct recruitment of 24 trained graduate teachers. The resignation for 1977 was 62 graduates and 191 non-graduates.

    The Member for Jurong would like to know whether the teacher quota and the capitation grant would be revised. I agree with him that the teacher quota has been in use for a number of years. Although there were revisions done previously, they were done quite sometime back. We are at the moment having a re-examination in the teaching load of the teachers. While this may result in the change of the quota or it may not, I cannot promise him. As for the capitation grant, we are looking into the matter. It is true that the capitation grant at the moment is not enough to meet the expenses it was intended. We are still looking into this matter and we are having a lot of discussions with the Ministry of Finance. I hope it may result in some upward revision but the matter is still not decided.

    As for principal's allowance also mentioned by the Member for Jurong, it has already been agreed to in principle by the PSC and the Ministry of Finance. As I mentioned earlier, the scheme of service is being revised. The principal's allowance will

Column: 1245

be implemented only after the scheme of service has been finalised.

    Sir, in view of the change in the medium of instruction for pre-university students, the Member for Jurong was worried and he wanted to know how the excess Chinese teachers would be deployed. I can assure him that they will not be retrenched because I agree with him that it is not their fault. Those who can be retrained will be retrained. For those who cannot be retrained because they are old or otherwise, we will find suitable employment for them within the Education Service. Of course, some sort of adjustments will have to be made.

    The Member suggested allowing teachers to go on educational tours as a means of reward for their service. This can be looked into. In principle, we do encourage our teachers to tour ASEAN countries to see for themselves. But the details will have to be worked out later.

    As for the raising of the standard of English in Chinese schools, I agree with the Member that the most important factor is to have more English Language teachers. Every assistance will be given by my Ministry to the Chinese schools in respect of the required number of English Language teachers. However, there are many other things which a school can do. For example, it could set up a language laboratory; it could have remedial classes; it could fix a day or more than one day a week for students to speak only English in order to break the psychological barrier towards more unfamiliar language. There are various methods that Chinese schools can adopt to improve the standard of English.

    My Ministry is prepared to give whatever assistance, including financial assistance, to help Chinese schools to raise the standard of English in the shortest possible time.

    The Member for Serangoon Gardens drew the attention of the House to the remarks made by the Director of Education who said that students are not asking questions. What I would like to say is that question-asking is an important educative process and should be encouraged. Teachers in general welcome questions from the pupils.

3.00 p.m.

    He complained that the attitudes of the Ministry's officials were wrong or that the officials were rude to the school teachers. I would like to say that all the officials of the Ministry have been specifically told of the importance of establishing a cordial working relationship with schools. If there is any evidence of harassment by them, appropriate action will be taken. If there is any specific instance of complaint that can be substantiated, I will look into it.

    The Member for Moulmein complained that the setting up of the Language Project Centre gives the wrong impression that those who attended the courses were unqualified or underqualified. I would like to clarify that it is not true that those who attended the course are unqualified or underqualified. They are all professionally trained teachers. No one can deny that we always have something more to learn. The teachers who attended the courses are not known as students. They attend as course participants. They can learn from the lecturers as well as from among the teachers.

    Transfer of teachers is unavoidable. It is not really possible to accede to every request for transfer. Personally, I do not believe that the transfers made recently, though large in number, were due to poor planning. There may be room for improvement, but sometimes time is a factor. If there is any case of genuine personal difficulties, where I can be of any help, I would appreciate it if he could let me know.

    The Member for Changi would like to know whether those who attend overseas training would get some sort of incentive when they return. My answer is yes. There is the incentive bonus payment as well as the incentive increments, depending on the type of training.

    I think I have replied to all the major queries. If I have left out any, please let me know.

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Sir, listening to the Senior Minister of State's reply, enumerating a long list of education

Column: 1247

programmes that his Ministry is presently carrying out, one cannot help but feel that the Education Ministry is taking on more than what it can chew. Let us hope that there will be no further announcements of any new educational innovations in the immediate future until the Ministry has finished sorting out its various problems in connection with the recent educational policy changes.

    The Senior Minister of State also mentioned that the survey which his Ministry conducted among teachers sometime ago showed that there was no evidence of low morale in the teaching profession. In fact, that point was brought up by the Member for Serangoon Gardens. I think he seemed to forget that this survey was conducted before the results of the promotion exercise were known and before the English Language Course was organised. So if his Ministry conducts a survey now, his Ministry will be surprised to find that the results will vary considerably from the results of the last survey.

     An hon. Member: How do you know?

     Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Sir, when the Senior Minister of State spoke on the question of raising the standard of English in Chinese schools, he stated that the Ministry would give every assistance, including financial assistance. He also suggested that schools themselves might set up language laboratories and take all such other steps, such as encouraging a greater use of English. But I notice that he very carefully steered away from committing himself to the question of sending more English Language teachers to Chinese schools. Recently, 28 Chinese primary schools were selected. I think we all know that these are presumably guinea pigs, and some English Language teachers were sent to these schools. I would just like to know whether the same treatment will be extended to the other Chinese primary schools.

    Only yesterday, in the Straits Times, we were reminded of the shocking standard of English in English schools. This seems to

Column: 1248

imply that the standard of teaching of English in English. schools is perhaps far from satisfactory. That would also seem to imply that there is a shortage of good English Language teachers. That being the case, how is he going to get sufficient teachers to be sent to Chinese schools, and how is he going to raise the standard of English in the Chinese schools?

     An hon. Member: 10 years more.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon (Serangoon Gardens): Sir, I would like to thank the Senior Minister of State for his satisfactory answer to some of the points I have raised. However, I cannot agree with him with regard to his assertion that it is incorrect to say that the morale of the teachers is low.

    Sir, 9,696 teachers were invited for the promotion exercise, 473 teachers were promoted. This means that there were 9,223 failures in the promotion exercise, including those who did not turn up for the interview. This constitutes more than 50% of members in the teaching profession, one in every two teachers failed to be promoted or were disappointed with the promotion exercise. I am sure that having failed in a particular exercise, there must be very widespread frustration and disappointment among the teachers concerned. In fact, some of these teachers expressed the view that it would have been better if they had not been called up at all.

     An hon. Member: Quite true.

     Dr Lau Teik Soon: Sir, I was astonished to hear from the Senior Minister of State saying that apart from the exercise being one to promote teachers, it was also one to establish direct contact with teachers. Surely there are other avenues which the Senior Minister of State can think of by which teachers can express their views with regard to the education service. It may be useful for example, to consider establishing at the Ministry of Education a "Meet-the-Teachers" session, very similar to the session that Members of Parliament have.

    Turning to a more serious point of contention, a point which the Senior Minister of State did not answer, and that is, what are the criteria for promotion? I think here there needs to be a re-evaluation of the procedures for providing incentives to both young and senior teachers. If I may suggest, the Senior Minister of State should consider the following procedures for future exercises. In the first place, if it is made known to teachers that all of them will be considered for either merit increment or promotion, then there would be no discrimination. But the award of either merit increment or promotion should be based on the following criteria: Teaching capabilities: the way they present their lessons in class; the way they correct the exercise books, their punctuality, and so on. Secondly, their participation in extracurricular activities. Thirdly, their involvement in community service. Fourthly, their seniority. If these four criteria are made known, then every teacher will know clearly that it is desirable to be efficient in his teaching methods. It is desirable that he pays attention to the work of the pupils. It is desirable to participate in extracurricular activities. It is desirable to be involved in community service. If any one of them opts out of these, then he will be aware that he has a less likely chance of being considered. I mentioned "seniority" because in the last promotion exercise, many young teachers were given more than 16 increments or more than double their original pay. This can be resolved if merit increments are awarded to the younger teachers. This too will give them the incentive. They know that they will be considered for one or two merit increments if they fulfil these criteria. For the more senior teachers, promotion should be considered where the difference between their present pay and the promotion pay is in the region of just $100 or $200; this would be a fair and more just exercise in my view.

    Finally, the Senior Minister of State mentioned that the Ministry would be considering giving allowances to the Principals. I hope he would extend this system of allowance to the Senior Assistants in the schools as well. The Senior Assistants, as we all know, fulfil the responsibilities of

Column: 1250

the Principals in their absence. They have to draw up the time-tables and this often occurs during the vacation when the Principal is away. The Senior Assistant is responsible for the overall supervision of school activities and so on. I think it is also opportune at this stage if the Ministry is considering giving the allowances to the Principals to do the same thing for the Senior Assistants.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, the Senior Minister of State made the point that school teachers are giving every encouragement to pupils to ask questions so that they would have a discerning mind and do not receive ideas very passively and indiscriminately. Sir, I am also a teacher at the tertiary level. I teach in the University of Singapore and the students that I get are the end-products of our school system. I am very disappointed to report to this House that after nearly 10 years of teaching I find that there has been very little improvement in this regard. The students who attend lectures, tutorials and seminars are very passive and they have to be prodded to ask questions. This is something of fundamental importance to Singapore's survival because we face external circumstances and challenges that have to be met not by Singaporeans who are easily indoctrinated and very passive-minded but Singaporeans who have a discerning and inquiring mind and are able to choose and discriminate between the good and the bad. So I hope that instead of dismissing the point with a one-statement sentence, the Senior Minister of State would give very serious and long thought to this problem and devise ways and means of getting the right message across to our teachers. Perhaps the teachers have become too docile, being recipients of umpteen regulations. I think many Backbenchers have continually impressed upon this House on the number of regulations that teachers have to face. Maybe there is something there that the teachers themselves are somehow brow-beaten into a submissive frame of mind that they are no longer capable of thinking for themselves, let alone stimulate the thinking in their pupils.

     Mr Tan Cheng San (Paya Lebar)( In Mandarin): Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Minister of State whether the Government has the intention to strengthen the knowledge of the students on tripartism, that is, the fostering of relations and cooperation between management, labour and Government, in other words, to include the subject of trade unionism and tripartism as part and parcel of the curriculum in the Secondary school or Pre-university level.

     Mr Chai Chong Yii: Sir, I will answer the Member for Paya Lebar first. I have already replied to that question last evening but unfortunately the Member for Paya Lebar owing to some commitment, was not present at that time. Sir, I would like to repeat again. At the moment, this topic is included in Civics and General Affairs in the secondary school and, at the Pre-university level, it is included in the General Paper. Even Economics touch on this topic. But at the moment the curriculum is really quite heavily loaded. We cannot have a separate subject on that basis.

    Being a lecturer, the Member for Whampoa knows the problem. It is not a matter of giving sufficient thought. As we all know, there are a thousand and one things we would like to do in our schools. We would like our students to do this, to do that and to be the best in the world. The point is how. We do give a lot of thought to that. But how to do it? That is exactly the question. To be very honest, perhaps he knows more about the students' reaction than I do. I have to concede this point because he comes into contact with students more than I do. If he has any suggestions that are of practical value, I am always willing to listen to him and put them into practice.

    The Member for Serangoon Gardens said that I did not give the criteria. I did give them but only the general criteria. I cannot give the very minute details. It is more or less as what he has said - ECA, community service, etc. It is very general, a broad outline. I do agree that these are the main criteria. Sometimes it is very difficult to say whether one person's teaching is better than another because it

Column: 1252

can be quite subjective. That is why we are now revising,the staff confidential report and hopefully we can have a more objective reporting system.
